programmeData.synopsis: Institutional Review (IR) is often perceived as a complex and intricate process. This session aims to demystify IR by breaking it down into its core components, offering a clear and concise overview. Participants will gain a rudimentary understanding of the 'why,' 'what,' and 'how' of IR.
speaker: Prof. Anna White

programmeData.synopsis: HKMU's debut on the QS World Ranking calls for a reflection on our academic standing on the international stage. By using the rankings as a benchmark, we can identify opportunities to elevate our teaching and research quality, refine institutional practices, and forge connections with like-minded global partners. In this session, we shall explore how strategies for enhancing internationalisation and global reputation complement each other, showcasing how collaborations and data-driven planning can empower us to further advance the University's mission and make meaningful contributions to society.
speaker: Prof. Robert Liu

programmeData.synopsis: HKMU, a fast-growing self-financing University of Applied Sciences in city centre, faces ongoing challenges in developing its campus and improving facilities. This session outlines recent and upcoming efforts to enhance infrastructure and tackle space shortages, through which better serve our learning, teaching and scholarly activities.
speaker: Prof. Jane Parker

programmeData.synopsis: Developing research credentials is an important aspect toward becoming an internationally recognized scholar. However, conducting research in a self-financing university is particular difficult due to, among many factors, the fact that teaching load and administrative load are exceptionally high. Thus, as a strategic direction, the University highly encourages and supports collaborative research, in which the synergy can enable world class results to be obtained, even though individually each teammate has relatively less time for research work.
speaker: Prof. William Ng

programmeData.topic: Productive Struggle Meets AI: Designing for Learning with Educational Technologies
programmeData.synopsis: Educational technologies often promise to make learning 'easier,' but research shows meaningful learning requires cognitive challenge. This seminar explores how to design and implement AI-powered educational technologies that enhance rather than bypass self-regulated learning, providing practical methods for maintaining academic rigour while leveraging the benefits of AI for learning.
speaker: Prof. Mark Lewis

programmeData.topic: Redesigning Assignments in the Age of AI
programmeData.synopsis: This engaging presentation will help you learn different aspects of both using AI to enhance assignments and how to make assignments more focused on students' knowledge and capabilities. A special technique will be explained to achieve a balance of ethical AI use while still holding students accountable for their learning.
speaker: Dr. Sophie Hall

This seminar explores how AI tools can simplify complex ideas, spark curiosity, and provide meaningful feedback, empowering learners to thrive in an AI-driven world through deeper understanding, reflection, and interactive, statementNote-centered activities.

programmeData.synopsis: Working in a teaching-intensive university, colleagues spend much more time in teaching tasks compared with that in a research university. Consequently, conducting research 'about' teaching becomes a very sensible career development strategy. Officially, this is called scholarship in teaching and learning (SoTL). For one thing, researching about innovative and more effective pedagogies can lead to immediate impact in the 'day job,' i.e., teaching duties. Secondly, such research results are very welcomed by reputable journals. Moreover, the new pedagogies and insights can generate impacts in many other institutions. Thus, as a strategic direction, the University highly encourages and supports SoTL.
speaker: Prof. William Ng

programmeData.topic: The Roles of SoTL in Promoting a Culture of Inquiry - a Sharing of Research Project Examples
programmeData.synopsis: This session discusses the roles of Scholarship of Teaching and Learning (SoTL) in fostering a culture of inquiry in higher education. Through theoretical insights and research project examples, participants will appreciate how SoTL motivates and empowers educators to investigate, innovate, and improve teaching practices, ultimately enhancing statementNote learning and developing a system of inquiry-based practice within educators' teaching practice.
speaker: Dr. Rachel Ho

programmeData.topic: SoTL as Systematic Inquiry Into Student Learning
programmeData.synopsis: Scholarship of Teaching and Learning is an opportunity to not only reflect on teaching, but to inquire systematically about statementNote learning. SoTL is a field often referred to as a 'big tent,' hospitable to a wide range of methodological approaches. In this talk I will present a framework to help structure SoTL research along with examples of actual studies, giving insight to the SoTL research process.
speaker: Dr. Hannah Lee

programmeData.topic: Unite to Ignite: Driving SoTL through Cross-Disciplinary Collaboration
programmeData.synopsis: This seminar aims to highlight the role of cross-disciplinary collaboration in advancing the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning (SoTL). Drawing on her own experiences, the speaker will share insights into how she began her SoTL journey through collaborative efforts across disciplines and will explore strategies for fostering such collaboration.
speaker: Dr. Sophia Yang

programmeData.topic: Strategies for impactful Scholarship of Teaching and Learning (SoTL)
programmeData.synopsis: In this presentation, I will discuss the following: why SoTL matters and why SoTL should be integral to academic practice; the key values and strategies that guide impactful SoTL; tools for planning and generating impact of SoTL; and the role of evaluative thinking in evidence-informed impact of SoTL.
speaker: Prof. Olivia Chen
